910A90F290364F719D8B06B8AFEA2B4B.description: Describe how Canadian and international copyright laws affect the lives of those who work in the jazz field.

041656BE6A544816A90A8D58FC681881.description: Justify or explore the statement that the jazz music of past eras lives on, not only in recordings but also in “ghost bands”, and with new, younger artists playing in the style of the greats of the past.

453C7FEB00C146368156FD2E4784909E.description: Investigate the influence of jazz in ‘pop’, ‘rock’, and other current music (e.g., the use of jazz themes and rhythms in hip-hop, rap, funk), and the influence of these current styles on jazz.

994E3B16ADA24C87B10DD54BCBB1B604.description: Examine the influence of jazz on current popular music styles with an emphasis on the music of Canada and Saskatchewan as possible.

458C2095E97F4BA7A3094196F76C196B.description: Research career avenues in jazz and music in general.

F05053282C7A4281982A817E72F90956.description: Discuss the influence of jazz on contemporary First Nations music.

9A29AB947B1D40C2BC4009B8B5A99C7A.description: Discuss the First Nations/American Indian heritage of jazz performers such as Oscar Pettiford, Art Farmer, and Jim Pepper and the effect of this heritage on their music and lives.

E05B3A478D41475BB4645901BAD21874.description: Identify influential players of the student’s instrument, investigate why these performers are so influential, listen to their music, and give special attention to performers from Saskatchewan and Canada

86F356329D524D759601DEC611BFC08B.description: A number of jazz artists have First Nations or American Indian heritage. Discuss possible reasons why this is not widely known (e.g., older performers Mildred Bailey and Dave Brubeck spoke to this, younger players such as Sharel Cassity and Julia Keefe have a different outlook).

78775AD1BB7748B2BE274EE539B38A71.description: Examine roles that jazz artists might have beyond being performers and identify individuals who fit those particular roles (e.g., Oscar Peterson/teacher, Wynton Marsalis/educator and Louis Armstrong/ambassador).

24A8973349BD41F6B071B77F3E299E7F.description: Explore jazz music and its performers and educators and their influence in the world.

BC39AB408E294D41A834FA0F431848F6.description: Experience through listening and/or playing “free jazz” (jazz music which is free from restraints such as key, form, metre, and changes).

C5D23BBCB884435988E9AB70D60E4E7E.description: Demonstrate awareness of jazz music by suggesting listening and/ or performing opportunities for the ensemble.

2AA31914142E40ABA7B065F0F4F9767A.description: Explore aspects of jazz such as history, performers, styles, and eras through a variety of media with a focus on Canadian or Saskatchewan jazz artists.

039A493F3A6048D39389EA741A77A03D.description: On first hearing, categorize jazz music into styles, genres, periods, and/or place.

03B364D02E9442CB859BB7F17BA20D43.description: Individually listen to recordings of jazz, develop a list or understanding of the basic characteristics of different jazz styles, genres, periods, and place, and implement that knowledge into practice and performance.

45F8CC6DA65A48B4BDDF8E520A17C402.description: Aurally distinguish the different eras, genres, styles, and feels of jazz by listening to and/or performing the representative music.

305E20EBAA6E4F689CDF1A50D14496B8.description: Cultural/Historical (CH): Students will investigate the content and aesthetics of jazz within cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts.

AA8483F41FA144A6B4DFE7F6F55E8E9F.description: Know the value of individual practice, know how to practice, conduct an ongoing evaluation of the student’s personal practice skills, and implement a plan to improve.

DD854422398949B18F2C5896A2DC2593.description: Be accepting of appropriate critiques from others and work towards implementing the solutions to that critique.

261F01C0EED2437699D09B8DAE3D947D.description: Critically examine and assess the student’s own individual work and personal contributions to group projects/performances.

CCD4AFEAB43B4350AFB74A9AC09F3579.description: Show respect for the personal work of self and others through appropriate critique.

3F20A8A972A64F2AA7EC749DAF96E381.description: Demonstrate a ‘professional’ attitude towards conduct, focus, and communication skills in rehearsal, preparation of materials, and presentation of products.

0581A148FFF54CE89DDF0C5F11FB1FB4.description: Demonstrate leadership as a performer by offering help, ideas, and guidance to other performers during rehearsal/practice.

D259F2534EAE41438CFFB7FFD7B700DC.description: Play in tune with good balance and tone and know the intonation tendencies of the student’s instrument.

DC775C0023E34264AEA49177809B8C27.description: Individually attend to melodic phrasing, rhythmic accuracy, and articulation in the preparation and performance of jazz.

772B6700A35F4310818E47E93006B039.description: Know the functions of all the sections within the student’s ensemble by demonstrating the ability to perform those specific tasks that are particular to the instrument that the student plays in the ensemble (e.g., comping for guitar and piano, walking lines for the bass, solo chairs in the horns, and position in a section).

762F776B3EAF44FEBF63AEDC246675A9.description: Demonstrate knowledge of, and personal implementation of, the skills, techniques and attitudes necessary for successful ensemble performance.

C352349F0A7842818F390F0A1AE795A7.description: Recognize and discuss the value of original thought, technical proficiency, place, era, and other concepts in the music of the great jazz performers.

8CC7120A94234D0FAE7363E9B2847C9D.description: Broaden knowledge of the skill and components of listening actively, continue to develop listening skills, and recognize that listening contributes to the authenticity of performances.

187F6AC30DAC4F23AB52F47222CFBC81.description: Upon first hearing a musical selection, describe and classify the music using appropriate jazz language (e.g. style, period, composer, culture, performer).

8D29863C2D4842D6964052EA0E719038.description: Design and implement a plan for improvement (personal and group) based on the criteria generated from listening to the great performers.

F1F18303906C4A11A51935B13DE5905C.description: Generate criteria of excellence through listening to the music of the great performers, (e.g., What is it that makes the music great? What do the great performers do that the student or student’s ensemble do not?).

26D8B76B6001422A9CE6CFCF4B0D84EF.description: Listen to the music of the great jazz performers.

19409049A45C4C11A7B4B585AB620860.description: Listen to performances of jazz music and individually develop and apply criteria to use in critical evaluation of one’s own and other’s work.

2BA966FFDE374BFFB7730AE0DD0C0CF8.description: Internalize and demonstrate the pattern of strong and weak beats that are identified with the time signatures.

EA1F862B36AD4AB3960895E494CC90C0.description: Clap on 2 and 4 on first hearing a piece of music in an appropriate time signature.

C6922314EC1C411E84A6C867160395ED.description: Identify the time signature on first hearing a piece of music, including odd metre times such as 7/8, 7/4, 11/8, and simpler time signatures.

DF220E225988425F934D0EC997CD15AD.description: Identify common chord progressions including but not limited to blues, rhythm changes, AABA, II-V-I, I-VI-II-V, in music performed and/or listened to (including progressions that break from the norm).

348B1B15BBF14BA6BFFFD153E01B941D.description: Individually identify, experiment with, and purposefully use strategies to solve different challenges related to music making.

2823B72A913944398E96F3E25694E384.description: Discuss the history, cultural heritage, and effect of current events as these apply to the musical selection.

0FE8EDF5D8BB47A0A1AB57402F8B226B.description: Analyze and reflect on the melody, bass line, fills (including drums and percussion) background lines, chord progression, roots, and sing along with the recording.

3A249BB695B54150A218F2E18521F1B7.description: Analyze and reflect on just one instrument from the beginning to the end of the musical selection (e.g., Did the player play the same way all the way through? How was it different or the same? What did he/she play that the student also might be able to play?)

46097A3F41B3427D9C5F8F1C54E82AE0.description: Identify performers and/or groups on recordings just by listening to the characteristic sounds or ideas presented in the music.

CC643379516B4B88AF5EDAC93EECC9E0.description: Analyze the characteristic sounds, licks, tone and and other elements of well-known players and/or groups.

C05848CA39DF40979404FCDB7B8F60B4.description: Analyze and reflect on the structure of the chord progression and the potential development of the chord progression.

EB421BD87C0841FB91BFD420A4534300.description: Analyze the development of the jazz music (head, arrangement, or improvisation) as a whole or in smaller sections

FCA93BD98BA24B549C2DA312583CDA31.description: Listen to jazz music and independently analyze form, tone, style, era, dynamics, articulation, time signature, characteristic rhythms, time, balance, blend, key, and/or pitch.

FFCD091320ED4ABEB872C3C25F745AA5.description: Listen to jazz as a jazz performer when not personally playing the music.

D5EF10FB540346A5AB0F4C9EEFEA4F9B.description: Know, predict, and/or anticipate what is next or might be next in the music and prepare for that while performing in the moment of the music

4921CEEAC67F4C03BF875A621BF5F324.description: Know any special emotional context that may apply to the music, generate the appropriate emotional feeling or energy, and/or change the personal emotional state of the performer to synchronize it with the emotional context of the music being performed

24A63343548A43EBB60D01BA8E1447D5.description: Recall previous experiences and knowledge (in music and in life) and integrate these into solo and group jazz performances.

88CA97BF97264FD9A514832613E88D7B.description: Know the history, culture, style, form, and tempo of the music being performed and respond to the music (written or not written) by reading the music and/or performing the notes and/or changes appropriately.

E9E2A669FB8949C0852B85240F73FB77.description: React to the audience, to their presence (or not), body language, expressions, and their reaction to the music (e.g. applause, cheering, being asked to play quieter).

B12B5B412140433080F8EB14113D9729.description: Listen to the acoustic properties of the performing space, including the sound, tone, loudness, and reverb of the room, and adjust playing accordingly.

9269D48B78CB450BB655C3558BB45F72.description: Respond to the conductor/leader, including his/her gestures, cues, tempo, expressions, and body language.

D317D393D0204DB69ECFEFE6D8BE39E1.description: Respond to the ensemble’s response to the student’s responding to them (e.g., when the lead player starts to play out or articulate a certain way, does the band follow and does the lead player recognize it?).

C250F7D356DF48FAA7A103F2E369F41C.description: Respond to the rest of the ensemble (e.g., their tone, pitch, dynamics, style, rhythm, time, balance, and blend).

5727633A0E764C7AB11ACA4D53E801A2.description: Respond to qualities of personal tone such as pitch, dynamics, style, rhythm, and time.

08D31A8CAE624663A4A7B9F49D8B17DE.description: Listen and respond as a jazz performer when playing jazz.

0F8028154497463ABDEFDC3820F7D144.description: Critical/Responsive (CR): Students will respond to artistic expressions of their own creation and of Saskatchewan, Canadian, and International artists using critical thinking, creativity, research, and collaborative inquiry.

CB32352731284396B0269684990536EA.description: Sight-read music at one level below the general level of the music being performed by the ensemble.

F417EAA4CE424744930CC3EF4C086CE3.description: Play both whole tone scales and all three diminished scales

E3646C2302684ACBB1B30D54EE1A6504.description: Play major, dorian, mixolydian, and blues scales in all 12 keys, two octaves when possible.

8152D2287DF647BD81D4394686FBE588.description: Play a full range chromatic scale.

BB79F25B6D9343B888B2B87A987C24DB.description: Having internalized the key concepts of playing expressively, demonstrate this knowledge through playing.

33FD326F20D04EACA2632FA0AFE16014.description: Play with a tone appropriate to the style and personal development.

2DA2862E0162463682BF1269D4C897A9.description: Generate technical inquiry questions and take action on the findings of the inquiry (e.g., “What can I do to get better?” or “How could I change this performance, paper, or arrangement?”).

68DF705C63B34CE183F1DC2FA43769FD.description: Demonstrate and record technical development and develop strategies to improve.

ED5FBD23E3C4424F9F1AD314657869D5.description: Show growth in individual instrumental techniques and knowledge of the elements of music and apply these to create or show a musical product.

62CF1125F5224E5F86E933E12798D0A0.description: Show proficient use of jazz vocabulary to relate jazz theory to personal musical practice, learning, and performance (see Jazz Glossary).

9CAF1D2FB0514230936305227C260D5A.description: Recognize and describe the standards of notation in jazz music that are different from traditional ”classical” notation (e.g., falls, doits, turns, and hats, as well as notation conventions such as how off-beat quarter notes should be written).

058FB418CD764159A3115926F168C5D2.description: Integrate into performance knowledge of standard notation conventions such as note durations up to 16th notes, codas, D.S.s, and dynamic markings.

6E70645A2CE94713A0397E9684CF3DF3.description: Integrate knowledge of conventions regarding jazz articulation, and use those conventions in performance.

470AC4BB1D9D48279D75F91514702AE8.description: Design, implement, and evaluate a personal plan to improve the individual performance process and to enhance knowledge and understanding of jazz (e.g., as part of the process of improvement, include recording and listening back to the performances, practices, and/or rehearsals).

BD04C66A015C43829D01491CA3FF6CDF.description: Recognize and define musical forms emphasizing rhythm changes in music that is listened to and/or performed.

CAD0BDA5AB544847B0422F9F14A73D56.description: Integrate the understanding of the different elements of music such as articulation, rhythm, beat, metre, time placement, and tone that help create a jazz style, and apply this knowledge while music making.

7B554621756C4D36870D5ABCDBF35668.description: Prepare, rehearse, and perform music in a jazz style in solo, small group, or large ensemble settings.

AE0F290B7C0E4DB7BA60A421F536AEC3.description: Infuse, independently, the understanding of jazz theory into personal musical performance.

D20AE6A4C452411E89950DA7B9B457B0.description: Improvise to show a personal, clear understanding of the function of guide tones within a musical form or chord progression.

A3B43C1593CE4ECAA2EB016A3DB6D8E8.description: Demonstrate through writing, describing, and/or playing, the understanding of jazz theory including: II-V-I and I-VI-II-V chord progressions, turnarounds,  modes of major and minor scales,  blues form, rhythm changes and 32-bar song form (AABA).

FAEC33E0DADB4400BA8C426CBE958C93.description: Take personal and musical risks by trying new ways to express oneself in the jazz idiom, using new ideas, new concepts, and a variety of styles.

4E1E9DCFF38642369D3E6165BCB6A15A.description: Demonstrate improvement and growth in the presentation and construction of improvised solos in a performance setting.

62505F2F92FD445B9C5D4DD2562592FA.description: Create simple, short three or four note jazz licks and develop these licks by methods such as: transposing,  transforming, adding single notes, decorating and connecting licks with segments of scales.

00AD5FE8E6CA47688D37749C7B280473.description: Play and/or transcribe recorded music of recognized performers through methods such as: play blues heads and simple and more complex jazz tunes by ear, sing roots of the chord progression of the solo, call and response with the teacher (or other students), sing and/or play along with solo, sing the solo being studied without listening to the recording at the same time, notate the solo including elements such as form, chord changes, pitches, rhythms articulations, and dynamics and start with short sections, such as a few bars or a single lick, and gradually increase the length and complexity of the selection.

A4C60387340A478D8D8DD781D16C2C88.description: To deepen understanding of jazz style, analyze musical events within a solo or composition (e.g., shout chorus, form, dynamics, pitches, changes, articulation).

8919DF2C009C453BA3AAF0E6BF0EFF7F.description: Improvise in a jazz style on an instrument showing understanding of applicable jazz theory.

4947702293A24C188F11D1F809702F96.description: Creative/Productive (CP) Students will inquire, create, and communicate through jazz.
